name: Yip, Yip, You're Dead: Druid 6/ Shifter 7/ Assassin27
author: webshaman1

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Here you have a master assassin in Kobold Commando shape!
Like the name suggests, it is inspired by Koolthursdays build; Death says Yip: Druid 7/ Shifter 7/ Assassin 26  from back in 2006, but I take it a bit further with this build.

This is a strength based shifter/assassin with HIPS, Devastating critical and a potent Death attack.
The build has very high stealth skills and great detection skills. It can open locks and set deadly traps in  human form.

Druid(6), Shifter(7), Assassin(27), Human
Alignment: NE, Any evil after lvl 13
Best in low- and mid magic environments. Tested level 1 to 40 in mid magic PvM

Pros:
HIPS and high stealth skills
Devastating critical shortsword, tailored to the Kobold Commando weapon. DC 40
Death attacks with DC 40 and damage bonus 18d6
Strength build for consistent damage
AB 42, high for a 3/4 BAB stealth build
Lock and trap skills
High detection skills
UMD
Improved invisibility with 50% concealment
You have access to other shapes, eg. Wyrmling for True seeing and Gargoyle for low level tanking
Druid feats add +2 to AB and +4 to stealth in wilderness areas. The spells One with the land and Camouflage add to stealth. Bull's strength buff the main attack stat, Ultravision complements the Assassin's Darkness spell.

Cons:
A bit low on hitpoints
No evasion
Cannot set traps in Kobold shape
Has 3 attacks per round with only 1 attack in the first flurry. A haste item will improve that and give 4 attacks with 2 in the first flurry. And HIPS let you repeat it all!


I have had great fun playing this little killer. I hope you enjoy it too!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Mirnaia wrote: You might have insinuated having something like this hiding in your closet yesterday :)
Kobolds are small, so knockdowns are 4 worse than you'd anthropomorphically expect.
Where do you test your builds, Mick?
Yes, I did promise something coming soon 
I took Improved KD. It compensates some for small size, but small creatures are always at a disadvantage when using the KD feats.
I play my builds in different modules, most of them end long before lvl 40. My minimum is to level my builds up to lvl 40 in a trainer, just to check that the build is possible and legal. The CBC is awonderful tool, but I don't trust it 100%, there have been some bugs. So I always test build my characters to se that they are legal.
This build I have played to lvl 40 in the Endless Nights module. You level up fast and can test playability at different levels without spending years in the process. The module has a strange mix between low magic items in the shops on one hand, and drops from bosses and chests on the other, that scale with character level to something between +6 and +9 and the occasional high magic item, depending on how "lucky" you are. But it is almost impossible to plan on a given set of equipment. In general you end up with something in the middle; something good and something bad. The average is probably what you will call mid magic. If I happen to get an item with too high properties, I just drop it, because it will ruin the test and spoil the challenge. I don't pick up henchmen.

posts.author: francois.demers.4
posts.content: Nice concept of a build. It's a shame polymorphs can't use rogue skills or spells or you'll bet I'll be making so many shifter builds of all kind. Though, I would've traded some assassin levels for more shifter levels for something like Druid6/Shifter17/Assassin17 to get the epic kobold shape. This way, you'll get 2d6 less sneak attack damage but you'll get 2d4+3 more base damage, an additionnal 2d6 on critical strike, more THP and Dex, +6 weapon to pierce stronger damage reductions, and improved evasion. However, this may also imply to rework feats. I'm still new to the game mechanics so tell me if they're things that wouldn't work with my idea for future builds.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Thank you francois!
You can build with the epic Kobold shape and get a fine build. The epic shape gives a lot of improvements over the base one. Among other things, you get a +6 weapon and higher dexterity, and you get bonus damage from added SA damage on the "creature skin" and bonus weapon damage. There are some shifter assassin builds in the old archive that use the epic shape.
So why did I choose the base type with this build?
With the lower number of assassin levels you have to take with the epic shape, the Death attack DC becomes too low to compete with the fort saves of many lvl 40 creatures. You can compensate for that by building up a high intelligence, but then you will not get high enough strength for Dev Crit and you will lose damage and even some AB.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Dropping IKD for Blind Fight would be fine but I don't recommend dropping KD unless it is useless on your server. IKD is taken to increase the chances of a successful knockdown since kobolds are small creatures, you should be able to manage with just KD although you will struggle against certain opponents (and any large or huge creatures will be immune).

Aside from disabling low-Discipline mobs such as mages, KD also lets you get more sneak attacks. If you're fighting something with high detect and See Invisibility or True Seeing you won't be able to generate sneak attacks by using HiPS or Invisibility, KD can help in that situation. Assuming that mobs on your server have decent AI, HiPS spamming and Invisibility alone will only give you sneak attacks on your first flurry. With KD you can get sneak attacks on two flurries per round, and if you combine HiPS and KD you can generate a sneak attack with every attack you make (provided that HiPS and KD work on your opponent).

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Well, you only get to be a level 5 druid, with a low Wis.

That makes things tougher at level 9, obviously.  You have next to no spells, even when you pump Wis (as I first did, like I normally do when playing a Druid - this build is not good that way, however).  The summons (III because of auto Animal Domain) are hopeless against what they have to fight at level 9 (which basically means fighting stuff over your level solo).  No real spells against such foes.  Don't even have Darkness as a spell to cast (for the Ultravision/Darkness combo).

UMD has been changed - it is now on Hardcore, meaning that not only does one need the 34+ now but also that the Caster Attribute thing is on now.  So that means one has to pump Wis on this build to cast from scrolls.

As for the merging - I was under the impression that Wildshape II has merging from these slots :
These polymorphs merge properties from any shield in the off-hand slot and the items in the amulet, belt, boots, cloak, ring, armor, and helmet slots.
Because that is what the wiki says.

But I did not notice my Belt of Gr. Piercing protection of /20 working, nor do I have anything from the boots slot (shouldn't that extra movement also be merged?).  I don't seem to be getting AC, Dex, Str, Con nor the elemental protections from the Chromatic Breastplate from my Amulet, cloak, ring, armor, and helmet slots at all.

Just wierd.

Not that it would be making a difference, even if I did.  Opponents just smash this build down in seconds (it is rare I see a 2nd round).  AC is WAAAAAAAY too low (I mean, I have, what, AC 22?  Max? doing Breastplate +3 and a Shield +3).  AB is 14/9, I can't hit anything, and if I shift, that just goes down further...Wyrmling, Gargoyle, and Mino are just useless.

This build just runs into a wall of pain at level 9 where I play.

I could try "cheesing" my way forwards - buying high level Druid Scrolls and pumping Wis to make the caster check - but that does not really speak much for the build doing it that way.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Just on the casting from scrolls, the hardcore check from UMD was activated recently
For those who are not aware of the details:
You must make a DC check of 25 + the level of the spell to cast a spell from a scroll if the difficulty mode of the game is set to Hardcore or higher.
This might be what you are experiencing, and to get the UMD score as high as possible would be what I would recommend before using scrolls.
It might be worth even hoarding a few eagle's splendors or +cha items
I am not sure increasing your wisdom attribute modifier would help with casting from scrolls, unless your environment has something modified in it.
From what I have read about UMD on the Wiki, because you are a Druid / Shifter / Assassin this means even druid scrolls will require a hardcore check, unless you have the spell in question memorized and ready to cast. 
Hope that helps

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Yep, yep - you're dead 
If you play in an environment where it is impossible to level shifters - then play something else.

What I will suggest for normal levelling is to play as a druid with summons and a companion to level 5 and hang back since the HPs are low.
With the druid wild shape you get str, dex and con overwritten, but your AC is low. You can have +3 natural AC from barkskin and + 2-5 str from bull's. Helmet, shield and armor merge, but AC doesn't stack normally when shifted and only the item with the best AC will affect the total AC.
Go with the best of these two tactics as long as possible.

The greater wildshape I gives several different wyrmlings. They are great for scouting with TS, but too weak for combat. They override str and your natural str is better. They are great for resisting elemental damage though.

Greater wildshape II gives the minotaur, the harpy and the gargoyle. The Minotaur is strong, but your character is stronger and the AC of the minotaur is not good enough with your low dex. The harpy has a special attack and that is that.
The Gargoyle is the best option here. it merges everything, except weapon and gloves (shifters in general never merge gloves). It does not override strength and that is a good thing since your strength is high. It overrides your weak dex and con to 18 for each of them. The base AC is 22 before you add spells and items. It has DR 15/+1 so it absorbs a lot of (most of) the damage from non magical weapons. And that also means that its creature attack is a +1 attack vs DR.

Greater wildshape III  has the basilisk, the manticore and the drider. The basilisk and manticore have their special attacks that maybe can solve special situations. The drider is a warrior with str 16, dex 16, con 15 and 20 AC. I think the Gargoyle is better most of the time, if not all the time.

Humanoid shape is where you get your kobold commando shape and the fun starts.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Orion, you left out that casting from scrolls in the same Class does an Attribute check now (part of the UMD scroll stuff that the Hardcore check brings with it).

Meaning if you do not have the required casting Attribute, you will not be able to cast the spell.

Period.

Example : Druid with Wis 12 tries to cast Summons VIII from a scroll.  Fails AUTOMATICALLY as Wis 12 cannot cast a level 8 spell.

Thus, one has to boost that Wis to 18 in this example, in order to cast the scroll spell Summons VIII.

What does work is temp boosting the Wis (with items/spells/potions, etc) to the required level and then casting the scroll spell.

It's a real PITA.

Moar jumping through hoops.  Tedious and tiresome.

Mkay, I'm going to cheese my way forwards!  For Yip Squeek! 

*grumbles about Limburger stench*

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
Couple things:  Webshaman's scroll casting example was not a good example.  Summon Creature VIII has both an arcane version and a divine version.  And then there's the default version.  If using the druid version, you should be able to cast from it without the need of UMD.  Emphasis on "should", but I have't read up on the HCR ruleset (the Wiki is of no avail in this situation unless they have an HCR section).

Regarding the build itself, anyone in most low to mid magic environments will have difficulty with this build at Level 8-10.  WIthout Monk AC or Improved Expertise, there's no way to make Wyrmling Shape (the tried and true way to level up a fledgling shifter) work for you.  I would frontload Assassin, still take Shifter1 to get there, and then gently massage in the Shifter levels.  I would raise Wisdom to 14 and take Druid to 8 so you can at least grab Stoneskin.  I see that Mick was tryign to get Humanoid Shape right straight away, but you could increase an AB point, and perhaps playability, if you postpone that until Level 23.  So play pre-epic as a Druid Assassin and go Druid8/Shifter4/Assassin8.

Regarding merging, it all depends on what form you're using.  Which form were you using when items weren't merging?

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Weapon properties stack with armor/item properties for shapes that merge weapons, so it's a choice between damage and +6 STR/CON. Armor/item properties merge onto the creature skin and so don't stack properly, but the creature skin and weapon (for shapes that have weapons) are separate and so those properties do stack properly.

For example, say you have +6 STR/DEX/CON on your armor, +6 DEX on your shield, and +6 STR/CON on your morningstar. When you shift you will have +12STR/CON and +6 DEX, since the STR/CON increase from the armor stacks with the STR/CON increase from the weapon, but the DEX increase from the armor does not stack with the DEX increase from the shield.

AB/EB bonuses will not stack with the shifted +6 EB short sword. Say you have +5 EB on your weapon, when you shift the short sword will have both +5 EB and +6 EB, but since only the highest EB matters the short sword stays as +6 EB. If you had a +7 EB weapon then the shifted weapon would have both +6 EB and +7 EB and thus would be a +7 EB weapon.

Personally I would just carry both weapons and switch as needed, encumbrance won't be an issue with this build. One of the few positives of item merging is that you can mix and match items at will. Only the properties matter, not the base item.

Also, the reason you only had electrical damage when shifted at level 25 is because only Epic Kobold Commando has bonus acid damage on their short sword. Pre-epic Kobold Commando only has +3 EB and On Hit: Poison. [https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Humanoid_shape]

Mkay.

After testing (level 34 now), the Morningstar is...incredible.  Having +12 to Str on this build shoots it into another league!  The Con of +12 almost hits 500 hps now. 

The Keen stacks (noice!) and Yunim is right, the Flame Weapon from the Wand *IS* on the EKC Shortsword.  I most likely missed it because I couldn't examine the weapon itself, Flame Weapon does not show up on the character sheet, and it is a 50% thing with the OnHit: Poison so I just missed the Fire damage.

It's there, I looked for it and found it (combat log).

Even against Acid immunes I was laying down the law.  So I beat up a certain Stone Giant King and his Bodyguard.  All at once.

I must admit, I was giggling like a madman at the sight of a little, itsey~bitsey kobold laying the smackdown on such huge and mighty opponents.

Then a dragon came and I was hard-pressed to survive.  This is where the extra Str really shined, as I Dev Critted that beast!

So I can actually see what Mick was going for with that, and how well it works with max Str.  Nice.

With only 6 levels to go, I will say the build is magnificent, with the exception (sorry to say this, really) of the levels between 15~20.  Those are the "I will pull out my hair, rip my own toenails out, and smash my own teeth to bits with a hammer" levels.  It's like the Marianas Trench of the build.

So perhaps there can be some refinement there - it couldn't hurt!

Also, in a +5 normal magic level environment, this build can be hard pressed to "cover the angles" in regards to pumping things.  Especially stats.  One really needs to keep a sharp lookout for weapons that carry stat bonuses.

Just knowing this little gem of knowledge is a big advantage.

AC is a massive juggle here.  I got lucky with a +6 piece, but that is all this build really gets, other than tumble and Dex bonus.  Even with consumables, there is not a lot of bang there.  Getting a +12 Dex bonus to the builds 22 Dex (EKC) would be nice (34 Dex, yes!) but I don't know really how one would do that.  AC bonus on a weapon is supposed to also add - dunno.

I will say this - playing a Shifter is like a giant puzzle, really different from any other type of NWN character build imo.  One builds it differently, and it plays differently.  The rules for what works (and what doesn't) is totally different from "normal" character builds.  Especially where I play, trying to lure a single opponent becomes a complex proceedure - because the form does not have missile capability (isn't that odd?  A kobold that cannot...throw or fire anything! O_o).  So one has to shift out, into either a form or normal, equip a ranged weapon/ability/spell and attract, switch back to melee weapon and shield (if it was not a sling, etc) and shift back to kobold (or whatever).

The build's offense is pretty good - it's not great, but it is not poor.  Damage output can be remarkably high under the right circumstances, and against certain foes, it becomes a little strained (like anything with vanilla True Seeing, immunity to Sneaks and Crits, etc).  Still, it performs well against DR type foes - I like that part of the build very much.  There is nothing like slinking from the shadows and really putting a brutal beatdown on an otherwise terrifying foe!

I was pleasantly surprised on how well the shortsword performs in this build.  With all things considered, a crit range from 15~20 is really good, the AB is high enough (~50 fully buffed), so crits and sneaks really do a lot of damage per hit.  For those that have skyhigh Fort saves, the Overwhelming Crit gives crits upwards of 100+ damage per hit, which really is fantastic to see.

I'll continue the build to 40, just to see if it gets any better - but all things considered at this point, I would definitely say that it is a good, solid build that Mick has given us here.  Only that little dip pre-epic remains a blemish on an otherwise great build.

Thanks, Mick, for letting us have this build.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Thank you Webshaman for sharing your playthrough on WoG with us. 
I agree with you that shifters can be difficult to understand and that much of the information you want is hard to find.
Your struggle also demonstrates what happens with shifters when the the level of magic items that a module is balanced with becomes too high. Any other character can just equip the items and things stack normally. With shifters the stacking of item properties is limited. That makes you depend on the properties of the different creature skins. And once they cannot compete with the stacking properties on a "normal" character type you are in trouble. Shifters are therefore definitely best in low magic environments, but they can also work in medium magic environments, depending on how things are balanced.
Some of the shifter forms are more viable as a focus for a given build. Kobold commando is one of them. You also have builds with focus on the Risen lord, Rakshasa and Dragon forms. Dragon is as far as I know the most popular and most often taken with Druid alone without Shifter.

What makes the Kobold Comando interesting in my opinion is that you get a very good stealth character that even has HIPS and that strength is not overwritten so you can build up both AB, damage and a high Dev crit DC when you focus on strength. You get some SA for free with the creature properties and you can pile up more if you take Assassin or BG as third class.
Bevare that Kobold commando SA and Rogue SA do not stack.
With this build I chose Assassin and took enough Assassin levels to get a high DA DC. Assassin also provides a long lasting Improved invisibility that becomes hard to dispel.
With NWN EE, Assassin is not as good as it used to be in terms of DA paralyzation, but the DA damage is still there. With this build you get a double first attack if you can haste yourself.

If you want to focus on the DA DC, it is even possible to build with a focus on intelligence. If you max out both intelligence and assassin levels, the DC becomes extremely high.

Edit: Stacking SA

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
I'm not planning on making a full shifter guide, but the best advice I can give to any potential shifter builder is: "If you can avoid building a shifter you probably shouldn't build a shifter."
I say this as somebody who has played a dedicated manticore build, a DC assassin dire bear, and even a smiting badger. Although shifters can be a lot of fun they are almost always terrible from a powerbuilding perspective. Some shapes offer advantages that can't be gained with non-shifter builds but you sacrifice a lot in order to focus on those shapes. Custom item merging helps mitigate some of these problems but even then you are still limited to only feats and potions while shifted.
As for decent shapes to focus in, from best to worst I'd probably say: Dragon, Rakshasa (1.69), Epic Kobold Commando, Risen Lord, Kobold Commando, and Stone Golem.
There are other shapes that can be useful but in my opinion are not good enough to be the focus of a decent build in vanilla NWN: Epic Drow Warrior, Vampire, Rakshasa (EE), Elemental Shape, Epic Drider, Epic Manticore, Epic Gargoyle, Mindflayer, and Wyrmling.

Rog kobold is a bad idea unless you really want that +6 EB weapon, just make a Rog/Figh/SD and enjoy your 4 APR and ability to use items. Rogue Sneak Attack doesn't stack with kobold Sneak Attack, both BG Sneak Attack and Death Attack do. Epic Kobold Commando gets Improved Evasion for free, and the best Rog feat (Epic Dodge) requires 25 DEX that is wasted when shifted. You can make a STR Rog kobold with Crippling Strike, but again I'd just suggest making a STR Rog/Figh/SD instead.

The only BG Kobold Commando build I like is a Dru5/Shif7/BG28 smiter but I would hesitate to call it a good build. Especially since Smite Good is less useful than Smite Evil in most PvM environments. None of the three classes have MS as a class skill, so even if you cross-class it and take ESF: MS at level 39 your stealth won't be good enough to HiPS against any competent listeners.

Poison stacks while shifted and will last until you deshift. I did some testing with Darkfire and Deadly Giant Bee Venom. Darkfire worked normally, triggering on every hit. Both poison effects worked, although after hitting 31 times the kobold poison triggered 4 times and the DGBV triggered 5 times. There were two attacks where both poison effects triggered for the same attack, so they definitely stack together properly.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Are you buffed with Owl's Insight when you shift? That would explain why you keep your druid spells.

When you shift/deshift the game removes and then reapplies all of your bonuses from items, as if you unequipped and then reequipped your gear. This means you temporarily lose WIS/INT/CHA or any items with the Bonus Spell Slot property, so when you shift/deshift you will lose spell slots. Any bonuses from spells, such as Owl's Insight, continue to apply during the shifting process and so you don't lose any of those slots. So you would still need to reslot after shifting even if you geared to get +12 INT from your armor, helmet, and shield slots. Unless your server changes how item merging works there is no way to fix this problem. 

This also applies to any CON bonuses, so be very careful when shifting/deshifting with low HP. It's possible to survive a very tough battle and then die when you deshift to heal yourself.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content: Assassin requires 8 ranks in Move Silently. Since neither Druid nor Shifter have MS as a class skill you need at least 13 combined levels of Druid and Shifter before you can cross-class MS to 8. This gives a choice between Dru6/Shif7/Ass27 or Dru5/Shif8/Ass27. Dru6/Shif7/Ass27 has +1 Will, extra Druid slots, and gives an extra Spellcraft dump compared to Dru5/Shif8/Ass27. There is no benefit to choosing Dru5/Shif8/Ass27 over Dru6/Shif7/Ass27.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
After some testing it looks like shifting has been improved slightly in EE. When you shift you no longer automatically lose all spell slots granted by WIS/INT/CHA bonuses from items. I did experience the same behaviour with spell slots but I haven't been able to duplicate it since so I'll need to do more testing. After the testing I've already done I'm certain that having the Bonus Spell Slot property is actually worse for shifters than not having it.

===

I'll focus on Druid/WIS and Dragon Shape (merges Armor, Helmet, Shield), but this applies to Cler/WIS and Wiz/INT too. I assume that it also applies to Pal/WIS and Rang/WIS but I haven't bothered to test it.

Say you have +12 WIS on your helmet. When you shift you have +12 WIS, and you keep all bonus spell slots granted by this +12 WIS when you deshift.

Say you have +6 WIS on your helmet and +6 WIS on your shield. When you shift you will have +6 WIS, and you keep all bonus spell slots granted by this +6 WIS when you deshift. Any spell slots granted by the additional +6 WIS you have when unshifted will be greyed out as if already cast.

Say you have +12 WIS on your boots (which don't merge). When you shift you won't have any bonus WIS, and all spell slots granted by the +12 WIS will be greyed out when you deshift.

Say you have +12 WIS on your helmet and a shield with the Bonus Spell Slot: Druid Level 9 property. When you shift you will have +12 WIS, and you keep all of the bonus spell slots granted by this +12 WIS when you deshift for spell levels 1-8. On level 9 the bonus spell slots granted by both the +12 WIS and Bonus Spell Slot property will be emptied (rather than greyed out).

Say you have +12 WIS on your helmet and boots (which don't merge) with the Bonus Spell Slot: Druid Level 9 property. When you shift you will have +12 WIS, and you keep all of the bonus spell slots granted by this +12 WIS when you deshift for spell levels 1-8. On level 9 the bonus spell slots granted by both the +12 WIS and Bonus Spell Slot property will be greyed out.

For polymorph forms, when you deshift any bonus slots granted by ability increases or Bonus Spell Slot properties will be greyed out but will not be emptied.

===

The ability increases work the same way for Sorc/CHA but the bonus slots work differently. I assume that this also applies to Bard/CHA but I haven't bothered to test it.

Say you have the Bonus Spell Slot: Sorcerer Level 9 property on x items that merge and on y items that don't merge. When you shift you will lose x+y level 9 Sorc spells and when you deshift you will lose another x level 9 Sorc spells. This is in addition to any spells lost from decreased CHA. You only lose spells from the CHA decrease once, but you lose spells from the Bonus Spell Slot property every time you shift/deshift. It's possible to lose every spell on a given level without casting any spells just by shifting and deshifting.

For polymorph forms, when you deshift any bonus slots granted by CHA increases are lost. If you have z items with the Bonus Spell Slot: Level 9 property then you will lose z level 9 Sorc spells when you shift. You only lose spells from the CHA decrease once, but you lose spells from the Bonus Spell Slot property every time you shift into a polymorph form.

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
webshaman1 wrote: ↑
Mar 26, 2020
Mkay.

After testing (level 34 now), the Morningstar is...incredible.  Having +12 to Str on this build shoots it into another league!  The Con of +12 almost hits 500 hps now. 

The Keen stacks (noice!) and Yunim is right, the Flame Weapon from the Wand *IS* on the EKC Shortsword.  I most likely missed it because I couldn't examine the weapon itself, Flame Weapon does not show up on the character sheet, and it is a 50% thing with the OnHit: Poison so I just missed the Fire damage.

It's there, I looked for it and found it (combat log).

Even against Acid immunes I was laying down the law.  So I beat up a certain Stone Giant King and his Bodyguard.  All at once.

I must admit, I was giggling like a madman at the sight of a little, itsey~bitsey kobold laying the smackdown on such huge and mighty opponents.

Then a dragon came and I was hard-pressed to survive.  This is where the extra Str really shined, as I Dev Critted that beast!

So I can actually see what Mick was going for with that, and how well it works with max Str.  Nice.

With only 6 levels to go, I will say the build is magnificent, with the exception (sorry to say this, really) of the levels between 15~20.  Those are the "I will pull out my hair, rip my own toenails out, and smash my own teeth to bits with a hammer" levels.  It's like the Marianas Trench of the build.

So perhaps there can be some refinement there - it couldn't hurt!

Also, in a +5 normal magic level environment, this build can be hard pressed to "cover the angles" in regards to pumping things.  Especially stats.  One really needs to keep a sharp lookout for weapons that carry stat bonuses.

Just knowing this little gem of knowledge is a big advantage.

AC is a massive juggle here.  I got lucky with a +6 piece, but that is all this build really gets, other than tumble and Dex bonus.  Even with consumables, there is not a lot of bang there.  Getting a +12 Dex bonus to the builds 22 Dex (EKC) would be nice (34 Dex, yes!) but I don't know really how one would do that.  AC bonus on a weapon is supposed to also add - dunno.

I will say this - playing a Shifter is like a giant puzzle, really different from any other type of NWN character build imo.  One builds it differently, and it plays differently.  The rules for what works (and what doesn't) is totally different from "normal" character builds.  Especially where I play, trying to lure a single opponent becomes a complex proceedure - because the form does not have missile capability (isn't that odd?  A kobold that cannot...throw or fire anything! O_o).  So one has to shift out, into either a form or normal, equip a ranged weapon/ability/spell and attract, switch back to melee weapon and shield (if it was not a sling, etc) and shift back to kobold (or whatever).

The build's offense is pretty good - it's not great, but it is not poor.  Damage output can be remarkably high under the right circumstances, and against certain foes, it becomes a little strained (like anything with vanilla True Seeing, immunity to Sneaks and Crits, etc).  Still, it performs well against DR type foes - I like that part of the build very much.  There is nothing like slinking from the shadows and really putting a brutal beatdown on an otherwise terrifying foe!

I was pleasantly surprised on how well the shortsword performs in this build.  With all things considered, a crit range from 15~20 is really good, the AB is high enough (~50 fully buffed), so crits and sneaks really do a lot of damage per hit.  For those that have skyhigh Fort saves, the Overwhelming Crit gives crits upwards of 100+ damage per hit, which really is fantastic to see.

I'll continue the build to 40, just to see if it gets any better - but all things considered at this point, I would definitely say that it is a good, solid build that Mick has given us here.  Only that little dip pre-epic remains a blemish on an otherwise great build.

Thanks, Mick, for letting us have this build.
Hey Web!!!

First and foremost, congrats on successfully playing a build that isn't intended to be played on a server like WoG. Like Mick said, if magic items grant you a better boon than the Kobold Commando sword, then the build will suck, comparatively. I presume that in a server where a +3 weapon with 1d6 of elemental damage and 1 extra property is the cream of the crop, this build would thrive. However, I have to say that even though I understand why Mick chose to make this build 6/7/27 for that extra 1 DA DC and 1d6 damage, I prefer the split used in Death Says Yip (coupled with a little shuffling of stats for at least 14 WIS) of 7/7/26. What that does for you in Vanilla NWN is it allows ALL your unarmed froms to pierce DR as though they were wielding a +5 weapon due to the Stoneskin spell. That works for Bear Wildshape, Gargoyle, Wyrmling, etc... This could be instrumental in surviving that PITA period between 15-20.

@Mick

I really like the concept of this build, but I don't think I'd have fun trying it, as IMO you lose WAY TOO MUCH in a dedicated build like this when you go Shifter without Monk levels. Defensively, as much as you try, you'll be very easy to hit and there's nothing you can do about that except HiPS. Kudos for extracting the most juice out of the idea, though! As always, Mick Dagger's Assassin are like Wolverine: "I'm the best at what I do". LOL
